H0.text: A ribosome transports the newly synthesized protein from the site of synthesis to the site of modification by the addition of a carbohydrate.

H1.text: The endoplasmic reticulum transports a newly synthesized protein from its site of synthesis to the site where the protein is modified by addition of a carbohydrate.

H2.text: The Golgi apparatus transports the newly synthesized protein from its site of synthesis to the site of modification where it receives a carbohydrate addition.

H3.text: A vacuole transports a newly synthesized protein from the site of synthesis to the site of carbohydrate modification in a cell.

A4.text: N-linked glycosylation: If the protein is properly folded, oligosaccharyltransferase recognizes the AA sequence NXS or NXT (with the S/T residue phosphorylated) and adds a 14-sugar backbone (2-N-acetylglucosamine, 9-branching mannose, and 3-glucose at the end) to the side-chain nitrogen of Asn.

A6.text: As they are synthesized, these proteins translocate into the ER lumen, where they are glycosylated.

A7.text: The vesicles containing the properly folded proteins then enter the Golgi apparatus.

A8.text: The Golgi apparatus is a major collection and dispatch station of protein products received from the endoplasmic reticulum.

A9.text: Addition of galactose and sialic acid occurs in the trans cisternae.
